position.marginalia_text: Nemo historicum, aut aliorum fere scriptorum, Decori est ubiq[ue] locorum observantior; aut vividae pariter, seriaq[ue] descriptionis tenacior, quam Livius. Ibiq[ue] semper maxime, ubi maxime opus, aut usus. Tam solerti iudicio est praeditus, et tanta discerione instructus noster historicus: omni verborum

marginalia.translation: Of the historians, or other writers practically, no-one more observes the decorum of the topics anywhere, than Livy does; and no-one sticks more consistently to a description that is both lively and serious. And especially always there, where it is most needed or useful. Such expert judgment our historian possesses and with such discrimination he is equipped - he is the most elegant throughout in any display of words and opinions

position.marginalia_text: De fortuna, et virtute Romanoru[m], ecce prudens, et politicus Plutarchi liber: qui Romanae historiae lectori utilissimus; Censori, aut critico pernecessarius est

marginalia.translation: About the fate and virtue of the Romans see Plutarch's perceptive and political book, which is very useful for the reader of Roman history and absolutely essential for the evaluator or critic

position.marginalia_text: Dionysius Halicarnassaeus Graece de Romanorum initiis, et primis urbis temporibus, ea eleganter, prudenterq[ue] tradit, quae a M. Varrone, hero suo acceperat, instructissimo Polyhistore. Graece etiam de rebus Romanis optime Polybius, Plutarchus, Dion a quo recentiaora quoq[ue] patefactae. Et, quod ad monarchiam spectat, magis regia. Halicarnassaeus, Polybius, Plutarchus, Dion, mea aurea specula rerum Romanarum. Sed ecce Livius, meum adimantinu[m] prisma: cum splendidissimis mundi luminibus, Sallustio, et Caesare; Tacito, et Suetonio; Valerio Maximo, et Frontino.

marginalia.translation: Dionysus of Halicarnassus gracefully and perceptively reports in Greek about the beginnings of the Romans and the first ages of the City the things he received from his master Marcus Varro, that exceedingly skilled polyhistor. Also in Greek about Roman matters there are Polybius, Plutarch, Cassus Dio, who also illuminated more recent times and more royal subjects, when regarding the monarchy. Dionysus, Polybius, Plutarch and Dio Cassius are my golden mirrors of Roman matters. Yet see Livy, my rock-solid prism, together with the brightests lights of the world, Sallust and Caesar, Tacitus and Suetonius, Valerius Maximus and Frontinus

position.marginalia_text: Quod imprudenter Romani deos Penates, qui Troiam custodire non poterant, sibi crediderint profuturos. Augustinus de Civitate Dei. l. I. c. 3. Quod eo tempore Aeneas in Italiam venerit, quo Labdon iudex praesidebat Hebraeis. l. 18. c. 19. De regibus Latii, quorum primaus Aeneas, et duodecimus Aventinus dii facti sunt. l. eod. c. 21. An debuerit diis Iliacis Roma committi. l. 3. c. 8. Quod Romani quosdam sibi Deos non ratione, sed adulatione instituerunt. l. 2. c. 15.

marginalia.translation: How imprudent the Romans were in believing that they might derive any benefit from the Penates (household gods), who could not protect Troy: Augustine City of God, bk. 1, c. 3. That Aeneas came to Italy at the time when Labdon presided as judge over the Hebrews: bk 18, c. 19. Of the kings of Latium, among whom, Aeneas, the first, and Aventinus, the twelfth, were made gods. The same bk, c. 21. Whether Rome ought to be entrusted to the Trojan Gods. Bk. 3, c. 8. That the Romans established certain of their gods through flattery, not reason. bk. 2, c. 15.
